title: Évenenement anthropocène
text:
##<reading>: Book by Christophe Bonneuil et Jean-Baptiste Fressoz that historicizes idea of the Anthropocene. 
Recommended by <julien-choppin> during his lecture. Speaks about historical division between earth and humanity, which was built from those studying the earth (geology is beyond us) in parallel with those studying people (human sciences dissociated from natural causes. The <anthropocene> necessitates a breakdown as the two clash into each other.
'La téléologie du devenir écologique de nos sociétés remplace celle du progrès' (p90ish).
P160: Wartime shipping infrastructures made by British to circumvent Napoleonic blockage of Scandinavian wood established trade network with US. Lay groundwork for mass immigration of 19th century.

title: Où atterrir?
text:
##<reading>: Book by Bruno Latour on formulating new political ground
Also from the <julien-choppin> reading list. Thesis that unregulated globalisation, migratory crisis, and suppression of threat of climate change all drawing from same central point, which we need to focus on.
Claims that we are all experiencing a fear of being deprived of our soil (privées de terre, p15). In developed countries by way of the eroding sense of ownership over our own soil in face of migrants; our fear structured by the very fear experienced by colonized subjects (think I understood that last point correctly).Also from the <julien-choppin> reading list.
